occurrences.line_text: And in his hand a windy fan did beare,
And in the wine a solemne oth they bynd
In wine and oyle they wash his woundes wide,
With wine and water fild vp to the hight,
Then gan they sprinckle all the posts with wine,
In wine and meats she flowd aboue the bancke,
With balme and wine and costly spicery,
A mighty Mazer bowle of wine was set,
All passers by, to tast their lushious wine,
That so faire wine-presse made the wine more sweet:
And cheared well with wine and spiceree:
A sacrament prophane in mistery of wine.
So proou'd it eke that gracious God of wine,
Surcharg'd with wine, were heedlesse and ill hedded.
And beare with you both wine and iuncates fit,
Ne drinke of wine, for wine they say is blood,
Ne drinke of wine, for wine they say is blood,
That so faire wine-presse made the wine more sweet:
They bring them wines of Greece and Araby,
Close vnder his left wing, then broad displayd.
But his late wounded wing vnseruiceable found.
And maketh him his wing in vaine to spend;
Whose other wing, now made vnmeete for flight,
At an Herneshaw, that lyes aloft on wing,
And to him playnd, how that false winged boy,
And with his winged heeles did tread the wind,
Or winged canuas with the wind to flie,
Bidding his winged vessell fairely forward fly.
Diuinely shone, and two sharpe winged sheares,
For as the winged wind his Tigre fled,
Her little sonne, the winged god of loue,
Which thither haunt, and with the winged boy
On which the winged boy in colours cleare
The winged boy did thrust into his throne,
And like a winged horse he tooke his flight,
Next after her the winged God himselfe
With winged feete, as nimble as the winde;
But streight the winged words out of his ballaunce flew.
And sent her winged thoughts, more swift then wind,
For loe the winged God, that woundeth harts,
Therefore the winged God, to let men weet,
With which her winged speed is let and crost,
And on his litle winges the dreame he bore
As if the wind him on his winges had borne,
And clapt on hie his coulourd winges twaine,
And his wingfooted coursers him did beare
But with his clownish hands their tender wings
His golden wings: his dreadfull hideous hed
The plumes of pride, and wings of vanitie,
His flaggy wings when forth he did display,
Then with his wauing wings displayed wyde,
Thought with his wings to stye aboue the ground;
And clapt his yron wings, as victor he did dwell.
With his vneuen wings did fiercely fall
In his light wings, is lifted vp to skye:
The Northerne wind his wings did broad display
Feare gaue her wings, and rage enforst my flight;
Did alwayes sore, beating his yron wings;
His painted nimble wings, and vanisht quite away.
Or who shall lend me wings, with which from ground
And some had wings, and some had clawes to teare,
And with their wicked wings them oft did smight,
Taketh his nimble wings, and soone away is gone.
With his wide wings vpon them fiercely fly,
Which after her his nimble wings doth straine,
With their light wings, the sights of semblants vaine:
Carried away with wings of speedy feare.
And searched euery way, through which his wings
Ile clip his wanton wings, that he no more shall fly.
He flyes about, and with his flaggy wings
And from Prince Arthur fled with wings of idle feare.
Thereto feare gaue her wings, and neede her courage taught.
An Egle, that with plumy wings doth sheare
Sweet Loue, that doth his golding wings embay
And with wide wings to beat the buxome ayre,
And wings it had with sundry colours dight,
The God of loue, with wings displayed wide,
Her selfe so deckt, her nimble wings displaid,
With nimble wings of gold and purple hew;
Vnder the wings of Isis all that night,
Carried with wings of feare, like fowle aghast,
That her brode spreading wings did wyde vnfold;
The cloth of state, and on their purpled wings
And Eagles wings, for scope and speedinesse,
Vppon her wide great wings, and strongly flew
His brode black wings had through the heauens wyde
But being bred vnder base shepheards wings,
As ashes pale of hew, and wingyheeld;
And euermore, when he began to winke,
To winne him worship, and her grace to haue,
For hoped loue to winne me certaine hate?
And hope to winne his Ladies heart that day,
Till she mote winne fit time for her desire,
To winne her liking vnto his delight:
Should either winne him one, or lye without the dore.
Ne which of them did winne, ne which were wonne.
Yee shall her winne, as I haue done in fight:
No wonder then, if that to winne the same
That for to winne the saddle, lost the steed.
To winne me honour by some noble gest,
By timely death shall winne her wished rest,
In which all stroue with perill to winne fame.
And though my land he first did winne away,
To winne the loue of the faire Pastorell;
And winnes an Oliue girlond for her meeds:
Blandamour winnes false Florimell,
Britomart winnes the prize from all,
That who so winnes her, may her haue by right:
Still winneth way, ne hath her compasse lost:
And did all winter as in sommer bud,
Like as a Snake, whom wearie winters teene,
As withered weed through cruell winters tine,
Like as the Moone in foggie winters night,
In winters wrathfull time, he forced him to flie.
When wintry storme his wrathfull wreck does threat,
The drops dry vp, and filth wipe cleane away:
And all thy wrongs will wipe out of my souenaunce.
Her Lions clawes he from her feete away did wipe.
With her soft garment wipes away the gore,
Wiping the teares from her suffused eyes,
And wiping out remembrance of all ill,
From her faire eyes wiping the deawy wet,
They softly wipt away the gelly blood
Fast bounden hand and foote with cords of wire,
To frame such subtile wire, so shinie cleare.
But the sage wisard telles, as he has red,
The wisard could no lenger beare her bord,
And strong aduizement of six wisards old,
Of famous Wisards, and with picturals
Therefore the antique wisards well inuented,
And if to those ï¿½gyptian wisards old,
But hasty heat tempring with sufferance wise,
Wringing her hands in wemens pitteous wise,
As many formes and shapes in seeming wise,
She thanked them in her disdainefull wise,
The wise Southsayer seeing so sad sight,
Of whom he learned had in secret wise
and learnes her wise beheast.
The Lyon stoup to him in lowly wise,
How to escape. At last in priuie wise
What man so wise, what earthly wit so ware,
But wise and warie was that noble Pere,
Aread in grauer wise, what I demaund of thee.
Is to be wise, and ware of like agein.
But me had warnd old Timons wise behest,
The eldest two most sober, chast, and wise,
Ne wanted ought, to shew her bounteous or wise.
Ylinked arme in arme in louely wise,
But wise Speranza gaue him comfort sweet,
Whom thus recouer'd by wise Patience,
By wise Fidelia? she doth thee require,
Then said that royall Pere in sober wise;
But now so wise and warie was the knight
Which when she heard, as in despightfull wise,
Through goodly handling and wise temperance.
Till through wise handling and faire gouernance,
More huge in strength, then wise in workes he was,
And that weake eld hath left thee nothing wise,
To which right well the wise do giue that name,
Was warie wise, and closely did awayt
And him dishabled quite. But he was wise
But he was wise, and warie of her will,
From drowning. But more happie he, then wise
Wise Socrates, who thereof quaffing glad
But he was warie wise in all his way,
Shewing her selfe both wise and liberall:
Did order all th'Achates in seemely wise,
The which them did in modest wise amate,
Faire Sir, (said she halfe in disdainefull wise,)
That either me too bold ye weene, this wise
He now was growne right wise, and wondrous sage.
But without dowre the wise Cordelia
The wise Elficleos in great Maiestie,
Long they thus trauelled in friendly wise,
In plainer wise to tell her grieuaunce she begonne.
For thy, she would not in discourteise wise,
There the wise Merlin whylome wont (they say)
Wise, warlike, personable, curteous, and kind.
With heauenly seed, whereof wise Pï¿½on sprong)
In loathly wise like to a carion corse,
And in that monstrous wise did to the world appere.
And to the Castle gate approcht in quiet wise.
But all in vaine, his woman was too wise,
All which disguized marcht in masking wise,
Shall find, that all the workes of those wise sages,
Marching in louely wise, that could deserue
Some, that Bellona in that warlike wise
That mote to none but to the warie wise appeare.
But answerd, Sir him wise I neuer held,
In louely wise, and sleepes, and sports, and playes;
Such Musicke is wise words with time concented,
Such vs'd wise Glauce to that wrathfull knight,
Sometimes estranging him in sterner wise,
And prou'd himselfe most foole, in what he seem'd most wise.
Two knights, that lincked rode in louely wise,
In wittie riddles, and in wise soothsayes,
Which whenas Cambell, that was stout and wise,
And turne both him and her to honour in this wise.
More wise they weend to make of loue delight,
And some that would seeme wise, their wonder turnd to dout.
In louely wise she gan that Lady greet,
And wise Cambina taking by her side
But entertaind him in so rude a wise,
Till on a day, as in his wonted wise
Nor that, which that wise King of Iurie framed,
But she in gentle wise me entertayned,
And Glaucus, that wise southsayes vnderstood;
Proud Priams towne. So wise is Nereus old,
And Panopï¿½, and wise Protomedï¿½a,
Liagore, much praisd for wise behests;
Some while he thought, by faire and humble wise
In goodly wise, whereof it tooke his name,
For take thy ballaunce, if thou be so wise,
In warlike wise, when Artegall did vew,
That they might execute her iudgements wise,
With which wise Nature did them strongly bynd,
Armies of louely lookes, and speeches wise,
In seemely wise, as them beseemed best:
With that his wife in friendly wise to deale,
Iust Dice, wise Eunomie, myld Eirene,
But he it well did ward with wise respect,
In lustlesse wise, as if against his will,
So taking counsell of a wise man red,
To whose wise read she hearkning, sent me streight
Which though I be not wise enough to frame,
The second not so strong but wise, Decetto;
The third nor strong nor wise, but spightfullest Defetto.
That rather needes wise read and discipline,
And kept so well his wise commaundements,
That in rude wise him asked, what he was,
And wondred much at Cupids iudg'ment wise,
After his rusticke wise, that well he weend,
But in that litle is both rich and wise.
Who with his wisedom won, him streight did choose
Yet wisedome warnes, whilest foot is in the gate,
He wondred at her wisedome heauenly rare,
Or that your wisedome will direct my thought,
Through wisedome of a matrone graue and hore;
And heare the wisedome of her words diuine.
Whose sober lookes her wisedome well descride:
Who with great wisedome, and graue eloquence
But of all wisedome be thou precedent,
The guilt I doe ascribe: deare wisedome bought too late.
Her wisedome did admire, and hearkned to her loring.
For wisedome is most riches; fooles therefore
But wisedomes powre, and temperaunces might,
Is wisely to aduise: now day is spent;
He that the stubborne Sprites can wisely tame,
And feates of armes did wisely vnderstand.
They binden vp so wisely, as they may,
Faire feeling words he wisely gan display,
Her wisely comforted all that she might,
Yet all with patience wisely she did beare;
Whilest with delight of that he wisely spake,
But mote I wisely you aduise to doon;
And both from rocks and flats it selfe could wisely saue.
And wisely watch to ward that deadly stowre:
To vse that sword so wisely as it ought.
To ease you of that ill, so wisely as I may.
Did wisely make, and good Agdistes call:
All, that I euer found so wisely stayd;
And said, his boat the way could wisely tell:
But in his eye his meaning wisely red,
In th'harts of men, them gouerne wisely well,
When Glauce thus gan wisely all vpknit;
And to the present neede it wisely vsd.
That trusty Squire he wisely well did moue
And all things secrete wisely could bewray,
But vertuous women wisely vnderstand,
Yet wisely moderated her owne smart,
Which he could wisely vse, and well apply,
Yet he, that could his wrath full wisely guyde,
So well and wisely did that good old Knight
Ne she lesse glad; for she so wisely did,
Yet he himselfe so well and wisely bore,
The Infant hearkned wisely to her tale,
Which he so wisely well did prosecute,
Well said the wiseman, now prou'd true by this,
And seeke to please, that now is counted wisemens threasure.
One that would wiser seeme, then all the rest,
And is the wisest now on earth I weene;
Yet haue from wisest ages hidden beene:
The wisest men, I weene, that liued in their ages.
By Phoebus doome, the wisest thought aliue,
That it could ouerreach the wisest earthly wight.
The wisest sight, to thinke gold that is bras.
To wish you backe returne with foule disgrace,
And henceforth euer wish, that like succeed it may.
That victory they dare not wish to either side.
Well mote yee thee, as well can wish your thought,
Least thou perhaps hereafter wish, and be withstood.
But wishing it far off, his idle wish doth lose.
You and your countrey both I wish welfare,
Oft did he wish, that Lady faire mote bee
And oftentimes doe wish it neuer had bene writ.
And doe not rather wish them soone expire,
That many wish to win for glorie vaine,
Nor hart could wish for any queint deuice,
And wish to life return'd againe to bee,
And inly wish, that in his powre it weare
Of my mishaps, art mou'd to wish me better,
And wish, that he part of his spoyle might share.
And wish thee grow in worship and great weale.
But rather wish, that some more noble hire,
Being his harts owne wish, and home with him did go.
And wish my lot were plast in such felicitie.
Of want, ne wish for more it to augment,
And wish the heauens so much had graced mee,
Yet wished tydings none of him vnto her brought.
There waiting long, to win the wished sight
Who had enough, yet wished euer more;
To come vnto his wished home in haste,
And to the world does bring long wished light;
And to the wished hauen bring thy weary barke.
But ere that wished day his beame disclosd,
Him kept from landing at his wished will;
Ne how to win the wished victory,
Her will to win vnto his wished end.
As though she wished to haue pleasd them all,
He by no meanes could wished ease obtaine:
Could she her wished freedome fro me wooe;
By timely death shall winne her wished rest,
So thence he wished her with him to wend,
That all men threw out vowes and wishes vaine.
Each wisheth to him selfe, and to the rest enuyes.
With hope of her some wishfull boot to haue.
Whereof she long had lackt the wishfull sight,
But wishing it far off, his idle wish doth lose.
That liues a loathed life, and wishing cannot die.
And wishing oft, that he were present there,
And therfore wisht me stay, till I more truth should fynd.
And to her selfe oft wisht like happinesse,
In vaine she wisht, that fate n'ould let her yet possesse.
And therefore wisht them without blot or blame,
Himselfe he wisht haue beene, then in so bad a stead.
All on her gazing wisht, and vowd, and prayd,
And wisht it were in her to doe him any grace.
But wisht, that with that shepheard he mote dwelling share.
Ne euer wist, but that she was the same,
Approching nigh, she wist it was the same,
The false resemblance of Deceipt, I wist
For well she wist, his crime could else be neuer cleare.
Ne wist yet, how his talants to vnfold;
Yet wist no creature, whence that heauenly sweet
He wist not whether blot of foule offence
They wist their houre was spe[n]t; the[n] each to rest him hyes.
Yet well he wist, that who so would contend
And did he wist not what in his auengement.
He wist himselfe amisse, and angry said;
Him to entrap vnwares another way he wist.
Ne wist he, what to thinke of that same sight,
Thereat they greatly were dismayd, ne wist
Yet wist her life at last must lincke in that same knot.
She woxe; yet wist she neither how, nor why,
She wist not, silly Mayd, what she did aile,
Yet wist, she was not well at ease perdy,
She wist not how t'amend, nor how it to withstond.
For of their comming well he wist afore,
Yet wist not what their wailing ment, yet did
Yet wist she nought thereof, but sore affright,
He wist not, how him to despoile of life,
Ne wist he how to turne, nor to what place;
Ne in that stownd wist, how her selfe to beare;
Her earnest mind, yet wist not what it might intend.
For well she wist, as true it was indeed,
That well she wist not what by them to gesse,
Albee vntrue she wist them by assay.
As if the conquest his he surely wist.
He wist right well, that it was Britomart,
Ne wist whether aboue she were, or vnder ground.
Yet who was that Belphebe, he ne wist;
So furiously, that ere he wist, he found
For well she wist now in a mighty hond,
He wist not how her thence away to bere;
And daunger well he wist long to continue there.
As he had lost him selfe, he wist not where;
Was troubled sore, ne wist well what to weene,
He much was troubled, ne wist what to doo.
Ne wist he what to thinke, or to deuise,
For well she wist this knight came, succour to supply.
And range through all the wood, where so he wist
Ne wist which way he through the foord mote pas.
Whom well he wist to be some enemy,
For well they wist, that Squire to be so bold,
Whenas these Knights arriu'd, they wist not where nor how.
He wist not to which side him to addresse.
That he which way to turne him scarcely wist:
And rapt with pleasaunce, wist not what to weene;
O helpe thou my weake wit, and sharpen my dull tong.
Which to expresse, he bends his gentle wit,
And spake the praises of the workmans wit;
Such wondrous science in mans wit to raine
And hides for shame. What wit of mortall wight
During which time her gentle wit she plyes,
Whose like in womens wit he neuer knew;
And all her wit in secret counsels spent,
What man so wise, what earthly wit so ware,
A thing without the compas of my wit:
The knight much wondred at his suddeine wit,
That weaker wit of man could neuer reach,
Cannot describe, nor wit of man can tell;
His practick wit, and his faire filed tong,
As her fantasticke wit did most delight,
Carelesse the man soone woxe, and his weake wit
He had a sharpe foresight, and working wit,
Ne can deuized be of mortall wit;
And wondrous wit to menage high affaires,
That seemd a worke of admirable wit;
Ne Poets wit, that passeth Painter farre
Thus farre forth pardon, sith that choicest wit
And either vowd with all their power and wit,
For liuing wit, I weene, cannot display
A worke of rare deuice, and wondrous wit.
At last the Nourse in her foolhardy wit
The baser wit, whose idle thoughts alway
By their aduise, and her owne wicked wit,
In her fraile wit, that now her quite forlore:
This fire be quencht by any wit or might,
O wondrous skill, and sweet wit of the man,
By any ridling skill, or commune wit.
In wauering wemens wit, that none can tell,
Of this and that, according to each wit:
Saluagesse sans finesse, shewing secret wit.
That all so soone as he by wit or art
But read to me, by what deuise or wit,
Ne signe of sence did shew, ne common wit,
The traines of wit, in wickednesse woxe bold,
For all that nature by her mother wit
That Virgins loue to win by wit or wile,
To which no wit of man may comen neare;
With many a gentle Muse, and many a learned wit.
And with magnificke might and wondrous wit
Another that would seeme to haue more wit,
And all the engins of her wit display;
A man of subtill wit and wicked minde,
But gathered vnto her her troubled wit,
Thereto both his owne wylie wit, (she sayd)
Doe spend my dayes, and bend my carelesse wit
And hearing th'answeres of his pregnant wit,
Yet could she not deuise by any wit,
With which his gentle words and goodly wit
A cruell witch her cursed will to wreake,
The wicked witch now seeing all this while
The false witch did my wrathfull hand with-hold;
And in the witch vnweeting ioyd long time,
The wicked witch, saying; In that faire face
And with her beares the fowle welfauourd witch:
The Witch approching gan him fairely greet,
Then tooke the angrie witch her golden cup,
So as she bad, that witch they disaraid,
Thus when they had the witch disrobed quight,
Where him that witch had thralled to her will,
By that same wicked witch, to worke vs dreed,
Was the faire Witch her selfe now solacing,
In which a witch did dwell, in loathly weedes,
Might by the witch or by her sonne compast:
The Witch creates a snowy Lady,
Through that false witch, and that foule aged dreuill,
Which that same witch had in this forme engraft,
Who with her witchcraft and misseeming sweete,
And witchcraft, she from farre did thither bring:
When Witches wont do penance for their crime)
And her due loues deriu'd to that vile witches share.
Vntill the witches speech she gan to heare,
That either seemes some cursed witches deed,
The witches sonne loues Florimell:
How hauing reft her from the witches sonne,
With which weake men thou witchest, to attend:
Sometime with witching smyles: but yet for nought,
Scoffing at him, that did her iustly wite,
My looser rimes (I wote) doth sharply wite,
Sith his own thought he knew most cleare from wite.
From blamefull blot, and free from all that wite,
Faire Venus sonne, that with thy cruell dart
And with thy mother milde come to mine ayde:
Come both, and with you bring triumphant Mart,
And with them eke, O Goddesse heauenly bright,
Till that infernall feend with foule vprore
Or wearied with bearing of her bag
The day with cloudes was suddeine ouercast,
Whose loftie trees yclad with sommers pride,
Not perceable with power of any starre:
With footing worne, and leading inward farre:
And foorth they passe, with pleasure forward led,
Led with delight, they thus beguile the way,
To wish you backe returne with foule disgrace,
Pointed with mortall sting. Of her there bred
And with his trenchand blade her boldly kept
Much daunted with that dint, her sence was dazd,
With doubled forces high aboue the ground:
Wherewith he grypt her gorge with so great paine,
With loathly frogs and toades, which eyes did lacke,
With timely pride aboue the Aegyptian vale,
That welnigh choked with the deadly stinke,
But with his clownish hands their tender wings
And strooke at her with more then manly force,
Groning full deadly, all with troublous feare,
Their bellies swolne he saw with fulnesse burst,
His foes haue slaine themselues, with whom he should contend.
And with the Lady backward sought to wend;
